items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30pm today and 1:30am tomorrow morning, Thursday 10th November. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.91mAODN at 12:30am, on Thursday 10th November, which is 0.43m above tide tables, wind Force 5, south-westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. No property flooding is expected. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This alert has now been removed as the tides have now passed. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
The high tide has peaked and do not expect to see similar impacts for today's tides.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

Levels remain high at Derwentwater due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
River levels will start to fall at the Lodore gauge later today, Wednesday 09/11/2022.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 5:00pm on 09/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels remain high at Derwentwater due to heavy rainfall over the last few days.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
River levels will start to fall at the Lodore gauge later today, Wednesday 09/11/2022. However, this alert will remain in place for at least the next few days due to high water levels affecting land around the lake. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on Thursday 10/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15pm today and 1:15am tomorrow morning, Thursday 10th November. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.68 mAODN at 12:15am, on Thursday 10th November, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind Force 5, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30pm today and 1:30am tomorrow morning, Thursday 10th November. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high at Battlesbrigde, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.91mAODN at 12:30am, on Thursday 10th November, which is 0.43m above tide tables, wind Force 5, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15pm today and 1:15am tomorrow morning, Thursday 10th November. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.68mAODN at 12:15am, on Thursday 10th November, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind Force 5, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This alert has now been removed as the tides have now passed. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Wednesday morning's tide from 05:00 to 07:45 on 09/11/2022 is higher than normal due to winds and large waves. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 16:00 on 09/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
Whilst the river levels in the area are starting to fall, the lake is rising and will remain high for at least the next few days and there will be flooding to low lying land. 
No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we are not expecting to issue any warning. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10.11.2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from the Thames Barrier to Putney Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: City of London, Greater London, Greenwich, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Wandsworth, Westminster

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.47mAOD at 13:45 on Wednesday 9th November.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 88 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next two days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.85mAOD at 14:45 on 09/11/22 and 4.81mAOD at 03:15 on 10/11/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 93 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 10/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between midnight tonight and 2:00am tomorrow morning, Thursday 10th November. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.46mAODN at 1:00am, on Thursday 10th November, which is 0.61m above tide tables, wind Force 4, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow.

The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. 

This flood alert has been removed. High tides on Wednesday 9th November are below levels of concern. Please take care on promenades and coastal roads. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain above the flood alert threshold on the Upper Wey at Godalming.
The forecast for the remainder of this week is for drier weather, therefore levels should continue to fall.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated later today 09/11/22, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The weather forecast for the remainder of the week is for dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, and tide levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding is expected, however, please take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Wednesday, 9/11/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further showers are forecast throughout today, 09/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thurdsay, 10/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this afternoon, 09/11/2022 and overnight.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.1m to 3.3m this evening 09/11/2022.   
We expect river levels to begin rising this afternoon, 09/11/2022. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 09/11/2022 by 19:00, or as the situation changes.

Another 20mm of rain Tuesday night has caused river levels along the Uck to rise. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads will continue until Wednesday evening, including affecting locations near Isfield Mill, Isfield Bridge and near the White Hart pub in Buxted. The River Uck through Buxted should begin to fall by 13:00 Wednesday 09/11/2022. In Isfield, the River Uck should finally begin to fall by 18:00 Wednesday 09/11/2022. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. The River Uck should return nearer to normal by Thursday. However, as it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 09/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 2pm today, 09/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield, Penshurst and particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. No further rainfall is forecast for today, 09/11/2022. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning on 10/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated this evening, 09/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Another 20mm of rain fell Tuesday night. This is causing the River Adur to rise again. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens throughout Wednesday. From 16:00 Wednesday the 09/11/2022, flood water could again approach riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. River levels should begin to fall from 22:00 on 09/11/2022 and return nearer to normal by Thursday afternoon. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 09/11/2022.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. In the past 24 hours a further 15mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. At Alverstone and Sandown, the river level is stabilising and will begin to fall in response to the rain recorded overnight. Today (Wednesday 9/11/22) some minor impact flooding of roads (including Golf Links and Moreton Common Road), and land is expected to continue. Isolated showers are forecast to continue into the evening (Wednesday 9/11/22). Whilst these showers may cause an increase in water level, property flooding is not expected. Additional rainfall may increase flood impacts on land, roads and possibly gardens. From Thursday (10/11/22), the weather remains dry and the situation will improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. We have been operating Bembridge sluice to help manage water levels at Brading Marshes. Please avoid walking, driving or cycling through ponded water. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 16:00 on Thursday 10/11/22.

The River Ouse almost returned to a near normal level, but another 15mm of rain fell Tuesday night. The River Ouse is now rising again. We are not expecting river levels to rise as high as last Thursday, Friday or Sunday. However, minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads along most of the Upper Ouse is likely on Wednesday, including at Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. Barcombe Mills Road and the Anchor Inn could again be affected by flood water. The river should begin to fall by around 16:00 09/11/2022 in its upper reaches, nearer Ardingly. Nearer Barcombe, river levels might not begin to fall until 22:00 09/11/2022. Some roads could become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road and at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. The rain has now cleared. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

Another 20mm of rain Tuesday night has caused river levels along the Cuckmere to rise. Minor flood impacts will affect Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly on Wednesday. In Alfriston, the river could rise to again affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, from 14:00 Wednesday 09/11/2022. River levels should begin to slowly fall in Hellingly by 16:00 on 09/11/2022, and a little earlier on Mill Lane. In Alfriston river levels might not begin to fall until the early hours of Thursday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding in Hellingly and Alfriston. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. Flood risk should reduce on the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers by Thursday. However, as it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 09/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high at locations in the Rother valley but are starting to fall slowly. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Light patchy rain is forecast today, Wednesday 9 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane and along the River Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. We are ready to use the flood defence scheme at Robertsbridge if required. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation, and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Wednesday 9 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The situation is improving, and no further flooding is expected in this area. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: Another 20mm of rain fell Tuesday night. This is causing the River Adur to rise again. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens throughout Wednesday. From 16:00 Wednesday 09/11/2022, flood water could again approach riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. River levels should begin to fall from 22:00 on 09/11/2022 and return nearer to normal by Thursday afternoon. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 09/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling gradually at locations between Yalding and Allington Lock, including Maidstone. Internal flooding of property is not expected. Light patchy rain is forecast today, Wednesday 9 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly riverside areas of Maidstone and along the River Medway. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Wednesday 9 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

Another 20mm of rain Tuesday night has caused river levels on the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers to rise. Minor flood impacts will affect Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly on Wednesday. A Flood Alert remains in force for these minor flood impacts. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding in Hellingly. River levels should begin to slowly fall in Hellingly by 13:00 near Mill Lane, and 16:00 09/11/2022 near Church Road and Station Road. River levels are expected to peak significantly lower than last Sunday and Thursday. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. Flood risk should reduce on the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers by Thursday. However, as it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will likely remove this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

The River Ouse had fallen significantly, but another 15mm of rain fell Tuesday night. The River Ouse is now rising again. We are not expecting river levels to rise as high as last Thursday, Friday or Sunday. However, minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads along most of the Upper Ouse is likely Wednesday. Including at Barcombe Mills Road. The Anchor Inn could again be affected by flood water. The river might not begin to fall until 22:00 09/11/2022 near Barcombe. Some roads could become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. The rain has now cleared. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. We are operating our structures at Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

Another 20mm of rain Tuesday night has caused river levels along the Cuckmere to rise. In Alfriston, the river could rise to again affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, from 14:00 Wednesday 09/11/2022. River levels might not begin to fall until the early hours of Thursday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding in Alfriston. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. Flood risk should reduce by Thursday. However, as it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend.  We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Light patchy rain is forecast today, Wednesday 9 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

The Western Rother is still high in Fittleworth, but slowly falling. A small amount of rain Tuesday night (10mm) will cause a small rise in river levels Wednesday at Iping, Stedham, Midhurst, Lodsbridge near Selham and on the River Lod. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads between Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. However, river levels are expected to remain significantly lower than last Sunday. River levels should begin to fall Wednesday afternoon, before returning nearer to normal Thursday afternoon. River levels in Fittleworth, however, will remain higher than normal until next week. The rain has now cleared east, beyond Sussex. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. Please keep property flood resilience measures installed at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth, if you have them, as a precaution. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

The Langney Haven is high and rising over each high tide. The next tide at 11:30 on Wednesday (09/11/2022) is forecast to be the highest of the week, but only 20cm higher than recent days. Minor flooding could affect gardens of Langney Green, and potentially approach properties at Langney Green too. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park could also be affected. Wednesday evening's tide at 23:45 09/11/2022 is forecast to be 20cm lower again, and tides will continue to fall for the rest of the week. The rain has now cleared east, beyond Sussex. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. This will also allow the river level to very slowly fall through Langney. However, river levels are expected to remain higher than normal until next week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

Another 25mm of rain fell Tuesday night. This has caused the Powdermill Stream to rise in Crowhurst. The rain has now cleared east, beyond Sussex and river levels in Crowhurst are now falling. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, the recreation ground, rural roads and gardens in Crowhurst might continue through Wednesday, but should gradually reduce. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. River levels in Crowhurst should return nearer to normal by Thursday. River levels in Bulverhythe could stay higher than normal until the end of the week, but only minor flood impacts affecting Bexhill Road Recreation Ground are currently predicted. Please be aware that there is a suggestion that unsettled weather could return next week. Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding significantly increases.

Thursday’s very early morning tide at 00:00 on 10/11/2022 is forecast to be 20cm lower than recent days. The total forecast tide is 5.99 metres Chart Datum (2.94 mAOD) at Littlehampton. It will be accompanied by strong Westerly Force 5 winds, but smaller waves than recent days. Minimal flood impacts could still affect land and fields at Climping over high tide, but impacts should be less than recent days. Tide levels and flood risk will reduce for the rest of the week, with lighter winds and smaller waves. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

Another 10mm of rain fell on Tuesday night. This will cause a small river rise along the Upper Arun during Wednesday morning. Minor flood impacts could affect fields, gardens and rural roads. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford, if you have them, as a precaution. However, between Horsham and Wanford, river levels are expected to remain significantly lower than last Friday and Sunday. River levels should begin to fall by 16:00 on 09/11/2022 in Horsham and 21:00 on 09/11/2022 at Wanford. Nearer Pallingham Lock, river levels have not yet fallen, and will remain steady until falling on Thursday. The rain has now cleared. The next five days are currently predicted to stay dry. However, as it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding significantly increases.

River levels are still high on the River Roding in Abridge, Buckhurst Hill and Loughton. There is still a risk of flooding today, Wednesday 9th November, to gardens, roads and low-lying land due to high river levels. 

The weather today should be mostly dry, allowing river levels to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and remain aware of the weather forecast. 
This message will be updated by 6pm today, or as the situation changes.

Another 20mm of rain has been recorded in the last 24 hours. This is causing the River Lox to rise again. We are not expecting property flooding. River levels should remain lower than seen on Monday, but minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads could continue until Thursday. Including near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. The River Lox should begin to fall by 20:00 Wednesday 09/11/2022 and return nearer to normal by Friday. The rain has now cleared east, beyond Sussex. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. However, as it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week, please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. Please continue to operate private water control structures in Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of property flooding significantly increases.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no further significant rain through today, Wednesday 9th November, and drier for the rest of the week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and very slowly rising near Shripney, Bersted and Felpham. Flood water will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, possibly parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, as well as land at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Aldingbourne Rife in Bersted could keep slowly rising until Wednesday evening (approximately 22:00 09/11/2022). Only minimal or minor flood impacts are currently expected in Barnham, where river levels are already falling. The rain has now cleared east, beyond Sussex. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. This will allow the river level to very slowly fall through Bersted. However, river levels are expected to remain higher than normal until next week. Please keep flood protection products in place in Barnham as a precaution, if you have them. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 09/11/2022.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, and tide levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding is expected, however, please take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding in the Rivers Clyst and Culm Area has now reduced. River levels are falling below levels of concern, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Showers are forecast for Wednesday 9th and Thursday 10th November, and river levels will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message: The risk of flooding in the River Teign Area has now reduced. River levels are falling below levels of concern, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Showers are forecast for Wednesday and Thursday and river levels will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

The River Arun at Pulborough is high, but slowly falling. Water will be extensive through fields and could affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Flooding could affect the A29 at Pulborough. Over the period of high tide, between 10:30 and 14:30 on 09/11/2022, water will be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. In Arundel, only minimal flood impacts are currently expected. Peak water levels are expected to be lower over Wednesday evening's tide. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry; we expect the river should slowly fall through Pulborough for the rest of the week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them, as a precaution. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 21:00 on 09/11/2022.

Thursday’s very early morning tide at 00:00 on 10/11/2022 is forecast to be 30cm lower than recent days. The total forecast tide is 4.88 metres Chart Datum (2.14 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. It will be accompanied by strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The tide will still flood Shore Road, Bosham, but should not affect Bosham High Street. Tide levels and flood risk will reduce for the rest of the week, with lighter winds and smaller waves. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

Levels on the Upper River Ure have now dropped below levels of concern. Further rainfall is forecast however we do not expect it to significantly affect levels. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
We have seen heavy rain across the area over the past week. Levels in the River Crane remain high but are falling slowly.
A high tide is expected at Richmond at around 2.45pm on Wednesday 09 November. Due to high fluvial flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates may not be able to close to hold back the incoming tide from the River Thames. As a result, the incoming tide may flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the fluvial flow already in the channel, will push levels very high. Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is possible, around Haliburton Road, Eve Road and Talbot Road, although we do not expect any flooding to buildings. Any flooding is likely to be of short duration covering the period around high tide.   

Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels.
This message will be updated at 7pm or as the situation changes.
